Elles  comptent acheter, du charbon de bois au niveau du village (en vrac qui sera mis dans des sacs) pour être revendus à Fana et au retour elles s’approvisionnent en articles divers sur le marché de Fana pour les  revendre au comptant, sur place à Fana même et dans le village de Balan à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent avoir 20.000 FCFA de bénéfice mensuel par personne. Une partie du bénéfice est réinvestie dans l’activité et l’autre est utilisée pour les besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group Garanti are married women who average 42 years of age and 3 children.  With their husband and children, they live in traditional families in the village of Balan, sub-prefecture of Fana, region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali. They know one another through ties of community and marriage. And they excel in buying and selling charcoal, firewood, and a variety of commonly consumed goods.  The women joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of sustaining their lucrative work.  They are now on their 11th group loan.  All the preceding loans have been properly repaid.  In the village, the women intend to buy some charcoal (unbundled, which will be put into sacks) to be resold in Fana.  Once back, they stock up on a variety of goods at the Fana marketplace and then resell them, cash or credit accepted, locally in Fana and even in Balan, to customers composed of women and men.  The group members hope to obtain a monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA per person.  A portion of the profits are reinvested in the business, and the other portion is used to meet family needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
La señora  SONIA tiene 27 años, vive en el distrito de LA ESPERANZA , provincia de TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal ESPERANZA UNIDA.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to de secundaria .
SONIA está casada, tiene 1 hijo de 3 meses  de edad quien depende económicamente de ella .
SONIA se dedica a la venta de verduras, menestras cocinadas y fruta en el mercado cercano a su casa.
El primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió en la compra de frutas y verduras al por mayor.
Este crédito de 800 nuevos soles lo utilizará para  comprar verduras y frutas al por mayor, menestras para sancochar y empezará a vender azúcar y arroz, ya que esta planificando tener un puesto de productos alimenticios.
SONIA sueña con  tener un puesto de productos alimenticios y vender al por mayor para obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Sonia is 27, and she lives in the La Esperanza district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. This entrepreneur attended school until the fifth year of high school. Sonia is married and has a three month old son who is economically dependent upon her. Sonia sells vegetables, cooked stews, and fruit in the market close to her house. With her first loan for 300 PEN she bought fruits and vegetables wholesale. With this loan for 800 PEN she will buy vegetables and fruits wholesale, mixed vegetables to boil, and she will start selling sugar and rice. She is planning on having a food stand. Sonia dreams of having a food stand and selling wholesale to obtain greater earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fruits and vegetables wholesale, stew, sugar, and rice

loans.name: Ngwa

texts.en:
A. was born in 1960. She is happily married to Amabo Peter and has three children. She is a very hard-working young lady. She was unhappy after the death of her sister and family members due to hardship. Although she did not complete school because of lack of home training, ignorance, and especially poverty, she is still determined to succeed in life and provide for her children what her parents could not provide for her. 

She plans to invest this loan in raising chickens and cows and selling gateau, a French almond cake. She is going to provide her community with chicken meat and food for her family and community. She will also sell the manure from the chickens to cultivate vegetables and farm products. Experience has taught her how to manage a business like this one. In addition, her farm is located in a very good area. 

She will used the profit from the loan to educate her grandchildren and provide necessities and medication for them. A. loves GHAPE because of the low interest and the social interactions among members. These interactions bolster her loan use and management.   

 The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy chicken, cows, and oil

loans.name: Angela

texts.es:
La señora ANGELA A. C. , tiene 46 años, vive en el distrito de LA ESPERANZA , provincia de TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal MUJERES EN ACCION.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to de secundaria, refiere que le hubiera gustado estudiar la carrera de Derecho pero por falta de recursos económicos de sus padres. Al terminar el colegió empezó a trabajar en casa, hasta que empezó a vender sandalias y regalos en un puesto del mercado que esta cerca de  su casa.
ANGELA es soltera y trabaja para apoyar a sus padres que son ancianos y para afrontar sus propios gastos.
Se dedica a la venta  de zapatillas y juguetes en el mercado cercano a su casa, refiere que ella ingresó a Manuela Ramos después de un viaje que realizaba a Lima para traer mercadería en el cual le robaron todo lo que traía y con el préstamo de  Manuela Ramos logró otra vez empezar con su negocio y seguir adelante.

El primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió en la compra de mas regalos y sandalias que trajo de la ciudad de Lima.
Este crédito de 1,100 nuevos soles lo utilizará para comprar zapatillas al por mayor y poder obtener mayores ganancias.
ANGELA sueña con ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Angela A. C. is 46, and she lives in the La Esperanza district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She belongs to the Mujeres en Accion Comunal Bank. This entrepreneur attended high school until the fifth year. She would have liked to have studied for a career in law, but could not because of her parents’ lack of economic resources. When she finished school she started to work at home. Then she started selling sandals and gifts at a stall in the market that is close to her house. Angela is single. She works to support her elderly parents and to pay for her own expenses. She sells shoes and toys in the market near her house. She joined Manuela Ramos after a trip she made to Lima for merchandise. On the trip she was robbed of all of the merchandise. With the loan from Manuela Ramos she was able to start her business again and get ahead. She used her first loan for 300 PEN to buy more toys and sandals that she brought from the city of Lima. With this loan for 1,100 PEN she will buy shoes wholesale and be able to get greater earnings. Angela dreams of expanding her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes wholesale

loans.name: Ines Ismelda

texts.es:
La señora INES ISMELDA C. G. tiene 72 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Usquil, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ines es Viuda y es socia del Banco Comunal Cachanchugo.
La empresaria es analfabeta, refiere que ella es la mayor de 8 hermanos por eso desde niña se dedicaba a la  jalca: desgranar maíz, cosechar las papas, dar de comer a los animales que cría.
Tiene 5 hijos mayores y ninguno depende económicamente de ella.
INES se dedica  a le venta de sal al por mayor que le llevan de Trujillo. Ella los lleva a vender al mercado de Usquil.
Con su primer crédito de 200 soles compró sus cuyes y empezó a dedicarse a la crianza y reproducción de cuyes.
Con este crédito de  400  soles, comprará sal al por mayor.
Ines tiene como sueño poder vender su sal también en los pueblos aledaños y obtener mayores ganancias.

loans.use: lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra de sal al por mayor.

loans.name: Mi Fortaleza En Cristo Group

texts.en:
Argelia P. is an associate of Esperanza International currently looking to take out her first loan. She lives in a modest home with cement walls and a cement ceiling in Santiago, a city in the northwest region of the Dominican Republic where running water and electricity are unreliable. She lives with her two children, ages 14 and 18.
Argelina runs a bakery out of her home, a trade for which she has received training, and hopes to expand it by purchasing more merchandise. Her bakery will become the family's main source of income since currently they do not have a regular source of income. She expects her family to be much better off after completing this loan and looks forward to ensuring a better education for her kids and improved nourisment for her family. She is very grateful to the donors for helping her achieve this goal.

loans.use: Bakery items

loans.name: Fru

texts.en:
Born on the 19th May 1967, R. is married with seven children; she lives in Ntamulung, a quarter in Bamenda, Cameroon. The death of her parents made her to be very frustrated because her parents were very supportive to her in taking care of her kids. She has also faced so many challenges in life such as the burnt of her home.  She intends to invest this loan in her petit trading business behind main market-Mankon she plans to purchase Tomatoes, Cabbage Garlic Carrot, green beans and plastics utensils. 
R. has been a GHAPE client since 2006 and this is her third loan. She has seen that there is a high demand in her community for food since one cannot live without food. She plans to contribute to her community by providing them with food and their basic commodities

This loan will help her financial situation by providing her with a quick turnover investment and high profits through her buying and selling business, R. do buy and sell of Plastic also in Bamenda to cover daily family expenses..
With the profits from this loan, R. plans to sponsor her children up to the university and increase the standard of living in her family as she will make sure her family eats well and stays healthy.  Finally, she hopes to place much of her profit into her personal savings account that GHAPE provided for her.  She is happy to take a loan with GHAPE and knows her success will be greater with each loan as she receives more business and life skills training from GHAPE.  
 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying of perishable food stuffs like tomatoes Cabbage, Carrot Plastics

loans.name: Mougnou Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Mougnou sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 47 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Balan,  sous-préfecture de Fana Région  de Koulikoro, République du Mali.
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage, de mariages et font essentiellement l’achat vente d’articles divers et la petite restauration (essentiellement les fritures et les friandises).
Ces femmes ont intégrés  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur onzième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles veulent acheter, une importante quantité d’articles divers (condiments alimentaires, farine de blé, huile alimentaires etc) sur le marché de Fana  qui seront revendus au comptant, en détail et à crédit dans le village de Balan à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. La petite restauration est faite dans le village pour des clients qui traversent le village et quelques gourmets, sans oublier les enfants. 
Elles comptent obtenir 15.000FCFA de bénéfice mensuel par personne. Avec ce prêt les bénéfices seront réinvestis dans l’activité et une partie sera utilisée pour les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The members of the group Mougnou are married women who average 47 years of age and 4 children.  With their husband and children, they live in traditional families, residing in the village of Balan, sub-prefecture of Fana, region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali.  They know one another through ties of community and marriage.  They essentially buy and sell various goods, and they work in food catering (essentially fried foods and sweets).   The women joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of sustaining their lucrative work.  They are now on their 11th group loan.  All the previous loans have been properly repaid. The group members want to buy a major quantity of goods (condiments, wheat flour, cooking oil, etc.) at the Fana marketplace.  These goods will be sold retail, cash or credit accepted, in the village of Balan to customers composed of women and men.  The food catering is operated in town for customers who go through the village and for a few gourmets, plus, let's not forget children.  The group members plan on obtaining a monthly profit of 15,000 franc CFA per person.  With this loan, the profits will be reinvested in the business, and a portion will be used to cover family expenses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils

loans.name: Patricia Gosvinda

texts.es:
La señora PATRICIA GOSVINDA S. R., tiene 45 años, vive en el distrito de LA ESPERANZA , provincia de TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal MUJERES EN ACCION.
La empresaria presenta estudios superiores de enfermería técnica ,luego ejerció su carrera durante 3 años pero al casarse se dedico a la crianza de su hijo y al hogar.
PATRICIA es casada y tiene 2 hijos quienes dependen económicamente de ella.
El mayor se encuentra en la universidad y el menor en el colegio.  Actualmente se dedica a la venta de regalos, también vende productos de belleza.  Paralelamente tiene otro negocio de alquiler de autos.
Hace 2 años con el apoyo económico de Manuela Ramos y al dinero que tenia ahorrado su esposo logró comprar su primer auto para alquilarlo para que hagan taxi.
Actualmente ya cuenta con 4 autos.

PATRICIA se dedica a la venta  de regalos y de productos de belleza .Así como al alquiler de taxis. El primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió en la compra de mas regalos que trajo de la ciudad de Lima y también en la compra de productos de  belleza.
Este crédito de 2,700 nuevos soles lo utilizará para comprar, junto con un dinero que tiene ahorrado, otro auto para su negocio del alquiler de autos.
PATRICIA sueña con ampliar su flota de taxis.

loans.use: lo utilizara para comprar otro auto para su negocio del alquiler de autos.

loans.name: Mariana Angelica

texts.es:
La señora MARIANA ANGELICA P. V., tiene 63 años, vive en el distrito de LA ESPERANZA , provincia de TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal MUJERES EN ACCION.
La empresaria presenta estudios técnicos de cosmetología, trabajó en la peluquería de su hija durante 2 años aproximadamente, pero posteriormente decidió abrir el negocio de locutorio.
MARIANA está casada , tiene 4 hijos, todos mayores y ninguno dependen económicamente de ella, al contrario ella cuenta con el apoyo de ellos.
MARIANA se dedica a atención de su locutorio que tiene en su casa
El primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió en la compra  de pollos, patos y gallinas que criaba y vendía en el mercado que esta cerca de su casa.
Este crédito de 1,000 nuevos soles lo utilizará para comprar 2 tarifadores y un monitor de computadora.
MARIANA sueña con ampliar su negocio de locutorio y poder también tener cabinas de Internet.

loans.use: lo utilizara para comprar 2 tarifadores, un monitor de computadora

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
La señora MARIA A. O. tiene 30 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Usquil, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Maria  es Casada y es socia del Banco comunal Cachanchugo II
Ella es analfabeta, refiere que sus padres nunca la enviaron al colegio y que ella desde niña se dedicó al campo.
Tiene 4 hijos y ninguno depende económicamente de ella y cuenta con el apoyo económico y moral de sus hijos.
Maria  se dedica  a la venta de comida y desayunos  a los trabajadores de Usquil.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles compró sus cuyes y empezó a dedicarse a la crianza y reproducción de cuyes.
Con este crédito de  400  soles, comprará de  valdes, bolsas, papa, huevos, azúcar y otros productos para la preparación de sus alimentos que llevará a Usquil.
Maria  tiene como sueño ahorrar dinero y comprar terrenos en donde sembrar maíz.

loans.use: lo invertirá en la compra de  valdes, bolsas, papa, huevos, azúcar, etc.

loans.name: Maria Dominga

texts.es:
La señora MARIA DOMINGA T. J. , tiene 47 años, vive en el distrito de LA ESPERANZA , provincia de TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal MUJERES EN ACCION.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 6to de primaria,  refiere que por falta de recursos económicos  no pudo estudiar más.
MARIA está casada , tiene 3 hijos todos pequeños que dependen económicamente de ella.
MARIA se dedica a la venta de ropa en el mercado cercano a su casa.
La ropa que vende la trae de Lima, pero también vende juguetes y regalos.
El primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió en la compra  ropa que trajo de Lima para vender en el mercado.
Este crédito de 500 nuevos soles lo utilizará para comprar ropa, juguetes y regalos.
MARIA DOMINGA sueña con  tener un stand en un centro comercial de Trujillo para vender su ropa , juguetes y regalos y obtener mayores ingresos.

loans.use: lo utilizara para comprar ropa, juguetes y regalos.

loans.name: Señor Pan De Azucar De Sacllo Group

texts.es:
El banco se denomina  “ SEÑOR PAN DE AZUCAR DE SACLLO”, este banco está situado en la comunidad de Sacllo ubicado en el distrito y provincia de Calca, en pleno corazón del valle sagrado de los antiguos Inkas.

Nuestros socios conforman este banco en su mayoría dos años continuos, siendo socios cumplidores, ellos alternan sus actividades del hogar con la agricultura, esta época ellos están arando sus tierras para hacer efectiva una nueva siembra de maíz, esta zona produce un grano grande y dulce, otros socios requieren el dinero para comprar animales menores como son cuyes y aves de corral, para la reproducción y la futura venta, algunos socios mas son docentes y otros tienen su tienda de abarrotes, todos en general tienen sus tierras y son agricultores, a parte de esta actividad alternan con diferentes comercios menores, ellos solicitan el préstamo para invertir el dinero en sus cultivos.

Nuestros socios se encuentran sumamente agradecidos por el préstamo otorgado comprometiéndose al pago de sus deudas en el plazo determinado.
texts.en:
The Señor Pan de Azucar de Sacllo bank is located in the Sacllo community, which is in the Calca district and province in the heart of the sacred valley of the ancient Incas. The members who make up this bank have mostly done so for two continuous years. They are dependable members. They alternate their activities between the home and farming. This time of year they are plowing their land to get it ready for a new planting of corn. This region produces a large and sweet grain. Other members need the money to buy small animals like guinea pigs and poultry to breed and later sell. Other members are teachers. Others have grocery stores. Generally, all of them have land and are farmers. Aside from this activity they alternate with different small businesses. They are asking for the loan to invest money in their crops. Our members are extremely grateful for the loan granted, and they promise to make all of their payments in the determined time frame.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizers and seeds to plant their crops and small livestock

loans.name: Maximina

texts.es:
La señora MAXIMINA C. M. tiene 62 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Usquil, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Maximina es divorciada y es socia del Banco Comunal Cachanchugo II.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 6to de primaria , refiere que desde pequeña se dedico al campo. Quedo embarazada a la edad de 17 años, tuvo una hija la cual ya no vive con ella.

A raíz de un problema familiar, Maximina abandonó el pueblo donde vivía en compañía de sus menores hijos y desde entonces vive en Cachanchugo.  Está separada de su segundo compromiso.
A pesar de su dolor y tristeza debido al problema familiar, ella sigue adelante junto a sus menores hijos.
Cuando llegó a Cachanchugo empezó a trabajar sembrando en las chacras de quienes la contrataban, pero luego también empezó a criar sus cuyes, cerdos y poco a poco logró sacar a sus hijos adelante.
Tiene 5 hijos y ninguno dependen económicamente de ella, cuenta con el apoyo económico y moral de ellos.
MAXIMINA se dedica  actualmente a sembrar maíz en sus chacras que   se encuentran en otro pueblo aledaño, pero por motivos de salud hace 1 semana que no esta yendo a la chacra.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles compró sus cuyes y empezó a dedicarse a la crianza y reproducción de cuyes.
Con este crédito de  400  soles, piensa invertir en arar y fertilizar sus tierras para su nueva cosecha de lenteja y maíz.
MAXIMINA espera con ansias la cosecha que será dentro de seis meses, con esa cosecha podrá ahorrar algo de dinero.
texts.en:
Maximina C. M. is 62 years old and lives in the Usquil district of Otuzco Province, La Libertad, Peru. She is divorced and is a member of the Cachanchugo II Communal Bank. She stayed in school only until grade 6 because at a young age she began working in the fields. She became pregnant at age 17 and had a daughter who no longer lives with her.

Because of family problems, Maximina left her home town with her young children, and since then has lived in Cachanchugo. She is separated from her second marriage. In spite of the pain and sadness of her family situation, she persevered, along with her children. When she arrived in Cachanchugo, she worked as a contract agricultural laborer. She began with planting, and later began caring for guinea pigs as well. Little by little, she was able to raise her five children who now are independent and give her economic and moral support.

Maximina now works planting corn in nearby farms but, because of health problems, she has recently not been able to work. With her first loan of 300 soles, Maximina bought guinea pigs and started into the business of raising them. With this loan of 400 soles ($150), she will till and fertilize her land for a new crop of lentils and corn. Maximina anxiously awaits the harvest, which will be within six months, because with her earnings she will be able to save some money.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Tilling and fertilizing land for a new crop of lentils and corn.

loans.name: Mary

texts.es:
La señora Mary, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Decididas”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martin, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 33 años y es madre de 05 hijos, los 05 que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando.

Tiene años dedicándose a este tipo de actividad, brindando servicios de movilidad urbana en su motokar. Su esposo se encarga de trasladarse por diferentes lugares de la Ciudad. Se inicio con el primer prestamo de Manuela Ramos, poco a poco fue ahorrando y con ese dinero fue comprando repuestos, para mejorar el servicio a los moradores de la comunidad.

 Con este préstamo de S/. 1,400.00,  comprará repuestos y aceites como: lubricantes, bocamasas, bujías; para así brindar un mejor servicio y atender mucho mejor al cliente.
Hoy en día es una mujer independiente, y es ella y su esposo quienes toman las decisiones y administran su negocio.

Mary nos cuenta: Que el pertenecer a un grupo de mujeres le ha ayudado a conocer mejor sus derechos y juntas  hacer que estas sean respetadas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mary belongs to the communal bank “Mujeres Decididas”, located in the district of Tarapoto, San Martin, in the San Martin state. She is married and 33 years old. She is mother of 5 children, all of them students who still depend upon her.

For years she has been dedicated to providing city transportation services using her “motokar”. Her husband is in charge of taking it to different parts of the city. Her activity has started with a first loan from Manuela Ramos. She gradually saved money that she used to buy spare parts in order to improve the services she provides to her community.

With this 1,400.00 new soles loan she will buy spare parts and oils such as: lubricants, wheel hubs and spark plugs. This way, she’ll be able to provide her clients a better service. Nowadays, Mary is an independent woman. Her husband and her decide and manage their business. Mary tells us that belonging to the women group helped her know better her rights and that together, they can make their rights be respected.


Translated from Spanish by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy spare parts and lubricants

loans.name: Nora

texts.es:
La señora  NORA S. A. D. A., tiene 37 años, vive en el distrito D. LA ESPERANZA , provincia D. TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal ESPERANZA UNIDA.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to D. secundaria,  no pudo continuar estudiando porque a la edad D. 17 años quedó embarazada D. su actual esposo.  Tiene 2 hijos quienes dependen económicamente D. ella , una se encuentra en el jardín y el otro en el colegio.
NORA se dedica a  la venta D. menús (comida) que venD. a los trabajadores D. las construcciones aledaña a su casa, pero los fines D. semana prepara en su domicilio ceviche, tallarines , papa a la huancaína, frito D. chancho (platos típicos) y también venD. cerveza y gaseosas.
El primer crédito D. 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió para comprar tapers, utensilios D. cocina y sacos D. arroz y papas.
Este crédito D. 700 nuevos soles lo utilizará para  comprar papas, arroz , aceite, menestras al por mayor y 2 juegos D. sillas y mesas para colocar en la sala D. su casa y poder vender los fines D. semana.
texts.en:
Sra. Nora S. A. D. A. is 37 years old, lives in the District of La Esperanza, Trujillo Province, Department of La Libertad – Perú. She is a member of the Communal Bank “Esperanza Unida” (United Hope).

This entrepreneur completed her studies through the 5th year of secondary school. She was not able to continue studying because she became pregnant at the age of 17 with her current husband. She has 2 dependent children, one in kindergarten and the other in high school.

Nora spends her time selling lunches to construction workers near her home. On the weekends, she prepares ceviche, pasta, Huancayo potatoes, and fried pork (a traditional dish). She also sells beer and soft drinks. With her first loan of 300 soles, she purchased tablecloths, kitchen utensils, and sacks of rice and potatoes.

Her current loan of 700 soles will be used to buy potatoes, rice, oil, and dried vegetables wholesale. She will also acquire 2 sets of chairs and tables to place in her living room when she sells food from home on the weekends.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase potatoes, rice, oil, dried vegetables, & 2 sets of tables and chairs

loans.name: La Union Group

texts.en:
Prudencia is one of the members of the La Union Village Bank. She is an associate of Esperanza International who is currently looking forward to receiving her fourth loan. She lives in a cement house with a zinc roof in Santiago, a town in the northwest of the Dominican Republic where running water and electricity are unreliable. She lives with her husband and is the mother of three children, ages 24, 28, and 30. 

Prudencia owns a "colmado," a small variety store, that she runs from her home. She has received business training and vocational training to be able to be successful in her job. With the loan, she plans to purchase more yucca, sweet potatoes, meat, chicken, salami, plantains, laundry detergent, and bleach, and to provide a larger selection for her customers. From the increase in business that she expects to get from the loan, she plans to improve her family's nutrition and keep investing in the business. She would like to thank all the donors for their support.

loans.use: Yucca, sweet potatoes, meat

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es:
La señora  GLADYS T. E. , tiene 56años, vive en el distrito de LA ESPERANZA , provincia de TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal ESPERANZA UNIDA.
La empresaria presenta estudios técnicos de corte y confección, refiere que antes de casarse se dedicaba a confeccionar ropa para niños, damas y caballeros , pero al casarse dejó de coser para dedicarse a su hogar.
GLADYS es casada , tiene 5 hijos todos mayores y ninguno depende económicamente de ella.
GLADYS se dedica a  la venta de desayunos y menús en el restaurante de su casa.
Su primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió para comprar utensilios de cocinas, sillas y mesas.
Este crédito de 700 nuevos soles lo utilizará para  comprar productos alimenticios al por mayor como: menestras, arroz, papas ,aceite, azúcar, etc
GLADYS sueña con tener una polleria y así obtener mejores ganancias.
texts.en:
Glays is 56 years old and lives in the La Esperanza district, Trujillo province, in the department of La Libertad, Perú.

She is a member of the ESPERANZA UNIDA Village Bank.

This businesswoman teaches cutting and tailoring techniques, something she has been doing since before she was married, making clothing for children, women, and men. When she married she stopped sewing to tend to the household.

Gladys is married and has five older children.

She sells breakfasts and a set menu from the restaurant in her house.

Her first loan of 300 soles was invested in the purchase of new kitchen utensils, chairs, and tables.

This loan of 700 soles will go towards the purchase of wholesale food items such as vegetable stews, rice, potatoes, oil, sugar, etc.

Gladys’ dream is to have a poultry store in order to increase her income.

Translated from Spanish by Laurie Paguio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase wholesale food products

loans.name: Gema Adriana

texts.es:
La señora Gema Adriana, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Decididas”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 28 años y 01 hijo, y uno que ya viene en camino y depende de ella. 

Gema Adriana, anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de salchipapa y como es una es una mujer que le gusta trabajar y generar sus propios ingresos sola, sin tener que depender de alguien, decidió poner su propio negocio de ventas de bebidas gasificadas. Es ella misma quien administra su negocio, sin tener un horario y un jefe. Nos cuenta que se inicio con S/. 300.00 y empezó comprando 03 paquetes de gaseosas,  vio que le iba muy bien y que le falto sus gaseosas, poco a poco fue invirtiendo mas y haciéndose muy conocida.

En la Actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio y ya es conocida por sus clientes y amigos del barrio.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, comprará mas bebidas como: gaseosas en diferentes sabores, tamaños y marcas como también agua mineral con gas y sin gas.
 
Gema Adriana, tiene muchas metas por adelante y se siente motivada por hacer realidad  lo que se propone. Esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla cuando mas lo necesitaba, es responsable con sus cuotas de pago y piensa seguir así.

loans.use: Comprará paquetes de gaseoas.

loans.name: Eli

texts.fr: G. Eli  est une jeune femme âgée de 23 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle habite à Lomé quartier Awatame.  Elle fait  le commerce des assiette. Avec ce prêt, elle voulait renforcer son commerce en achetant de divers assiettes pour revendre. Avec ce bénéfice, elle voudrait aider son mari dans ses devoirs de  famille.
texts.en:
G. Eli is a young woman, 23 years old, married, and the mother of two children.  She lives in Lomé in the Awatame district.  She has a business selling plates.  With this loan, she would like to bolster her business by buying an assortment of plates for resale.  With the profits, she would like to help her husband with his family duties.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To diversify her commerce

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es:
La señora MARIA DEL CARMEN A. D., tiene 51 años, vive en el distrito de LA ESPERANZA , provincia de TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal MUJERES EN ACCION.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to de secundaria.
MARIA DEL CARMEN está casada y tiene 5 hijos todos mayores y ninguno depende económicamente de ella, ella recibe el apoyo de sus hijos.
MARIA DEL CARMEN   se dedica a la venta ceviche, papa a la huancaína, ají de gallina, tallarines (comidas típicas) en el puesto del mercado cercano a su casa.
Ella se dedica a cocinar y su hija la ayuda a atender a los consumidores.
Su primer crédito de 200 nuevos soles lo invirtió en la compra de mas ollas, platos y utensilios de cocina.
Este crédito de 200 nuevos soles lo utilizará para comprar productos alimenticios al por mayor como: tallarín, papas, escabeches, aceite, etc
MARIA DEL CARMEN   sueña con tener un restaurante en su casa y así poder generar mayores ingresos..
texts.en:
Señora MARIA DEL CARMEN A. D. is 51 years old, and lives in the La Esperanza district, Trujillo province, La Libertad, Peru. She belongs to the communal bank "Mujeres en Accion," (Women in Action). This businesswoman has 5 years of education. Maria del Carmen is married and has 5 children, all of whom are adults and are not dependent on her; she receives some support from her children.

Maria del Carmen sells Peruvian specialties including ceviche (a citrus-marinated seafood dish), papa a la huancaína (a dish of sliced potatoes in spicy cheese sauce), ají de gallina (chicken in a spicy sauce), and pasta dishes from a market stand close to her house.

She cooks the food, and her daughter helps her to serve the customers. Her first loan of 200 nuevos soles was used to purchase more pots, plates and cooking utensils. This loan of 200 nuevos soles will be used to purchase food products at wholesale such as: pasta, potatoes, pickles, cooking oil, etc.

Maria del Carmen dreams of having a restaurant in her house, with which she could generate increased earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy food products at wholesale such as: pasta, potatoes, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Ediltrudes Agripina

texts.es:
La señora EDILTRUDES AGRIPINA tiene 65 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Usquil, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
EDILTRUDES está Casada y es socia del Banco Comunal Cachnchugo II.
La empresaria es analfabeta ya que desde niña se dedicó al campo y a la crianza de cerdos, cuyes, patos, gallinas, pavos,etc.
EDILTRUDES se dedica a la crianza de cerdos para luego matarlos y venderlos en la plaza de Usquil y también separa unos kilos para los fines de semana preparar frito, chuletas , adobo, chicharrón y venderlos a sus vecinos y trabajadores del campo.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles compró cuyes para criarlos y reproducirlos.
Con este crédito de 2,000  soles, comprará productos alimenticios como: arroz, azucar, gaseosa, jugos, aceite, etc, estos productos los compra en Usquil.  Actualmente ella cuenta con una pequeña tienda de comestibles que tiene en su casa.
EDILTRUDES tiene como sueño ampliar su negocio y así generar mayores ingresos.

loans.use: lo invertirá en la compra de productos alimenticios como: arroz, azucar, gaseosa, jugos, aceite, etc

loans.name: Bernabita Modesta

texts.es:
La señora BERNABITA MODESTA Z. C.  tiene 52 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Usquil, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
BERNABITA está casada y es socia del Banco Comunal Cachanchugo II.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 6to de primaria, porque desde esa edad empezó a dedicarse al campo.
MARIA se dedica a la venta de productos alimenticios en la pequeña tienda de comestibles que tiene en su casa.
Los productos se los envía en encomiendas un familiar que tiene en Trujillo y esto la beneficia porque lo compra a menor costo que en Usquil y puede ganar mas.
Con su primer crédito de 200 soles mando a traer de Trujillo jabones, aceite , papel higiénico, gaseosas y golosinas.
Con este crédito de 1,000 soles, comprará productos alimenticios para surtir su pequeña bodega de comestibles que tiene en su casa.
Maria sueña con ampliar su negocio y generar mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Sra. Bernabita Modesta Z. C. is 52 years old and lives in the District of Usquil, Otuzco Province, Department of La Libertad - Perú. She is married and a member of the Communal Bank “Cachanchugo II”.

This entrepreneur has a 6th grade education. She began working immediately after quitting school.

Bernabita sells food from the small grocery store that she operates out of her home. Her merchandise is shipped to her from a relative in Trujillo. This arrangement is advantageous because she can get products at a lower cost than in Usquil, which means she can earn more profit. Her first loan of 200 soles was used to buy soap, oil, toilet paper, sodas, and candy from Trujillo.

With this loan of 1000 soles, she will buy food products to restock her small grocery store. Maria dreams of expanding her business so that she can generate more revenue.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase food products to restock her store

loans.name: Juana Antonia

texts.es:
La señora JUANA ANTONIA A. C.  tiene 75 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Usquil, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Juana es Viuda y es socia del  Banco comunal Cachanchugo II.
La empresaria es analfabeta, refiere que ella es la mayor de 9 hermanos por eso su padre desde la edad de 5 años de dedicaba a la  jalca  desgranar maíz, cosechar las papas, dar de comer a los animales y también se dedicaba a ayudar a su madre con la crianza de sus hermanos menores preparando la comida, cuidando  a sus hermanos, aseándolos, etc ,
Tiene 9 hijos mayores y ninguno depende económicamente de ella.
Actualmente vive con una hija de 29 años quien es profesora y trabaja en Usquil y la apoya económicamente 
Juana se dedica  a la crianza de sus animales como: patos, pollos, gallinas. Pavos, cuyes etc
Que los lleva a vender al mercado de Usquil.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles compró sus cuyes y empezó a dedicarse a la crianza y reproducción de cuyes.
Con este crédito de 1,200  soles, comprará más animales y también como tiene áreas de chacras preparará la tierra para sembrar maíz.
Juana tiene como sueño aumentar la crianza de su animales y empezar con el sembrado de maíz para obtener  mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Sra. Juana Antonia A. C. is 75 years old and lives in the District of Usquil, Otuzco Province, Department of La Libertad, Perú. She is a widow and also a member of the Communal Bank “Cachanchugo II”.

This entrepreneur is illiterate and the oldest of 9 siblings. When she was 5 years old, her father taught her to shuck corn, harvest potatoes, and feed the animals. As she grew older, she helped her mother raise her younger siblings, prepare food, clean house, etc.

Sra. Juana has 9 adult children and all of them are financially independent. She lives with her 29 year old daughter, who works as a teacher in Usquil and supports her financially.

Sra. Juana raises animals such as ducks, chickens, turkeys, guinea pigs, etc. She then sells them at the market in Usquil. With her first loan of 300 soles, she purchased guinea pigs for breeding.

With her current loan of 1200 soles, she will buy more animals and prepare her land for planting corn. Sra. Juana dreams of increasing the number of animals for breeding and starting her corn crop for higher profits.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase animals & prepare her land for planting corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: achat des produits de beauté

loans.name: Celinda

texts.es:
La señora CELINDA A. A. tiene 45 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Usquil , provincia de Otuzco , departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to de secundaria.
Es madre soltera ye es socia del Banco comunal Cachanchugo II
Aspiraba con estudiar enfermería cuando terminó el colegio pero refiere que su padre le negó esa posibilidad y le pidió que se dedique a la jalca, pero ella decidió viajar a Trujillo conseguir un trabajo y poder sustentar sus gastos de estudios por si sola.
Llegó  a Trujillo a la edad de 19 años y empezó a trabajar de niñera de una bebe en una familia de Italianos durante 3 años .
Posteriormente a la edad de 21 años conoce al padre de su hijo quien la enamanoró , la embarazo y no se hizo responsable ni de ella ni de su hijo, motivo por el cual ella decide regresar a su pueblo de Cachanchugo embarazada y empieza a trabajar en la jalca, empieza con la crianza de cuyes y aprende a tejer el junco (planta de la zona) para hacer: carteras, sillas, petates, sombreros, etc

Celinda se dedica al tejido de junco y también contrata chicas que le ayuden a aumentar su producción haciendo: carteras, petates, bolsas y  sombreros, para luego  viajar a la ciudad de Cajamarca a venderlos .
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles compro junco, cintas, lanas, hilos, etc
Con este crédito de 1,000 lo invertirá en su negocio, en la compra de mas junco al por mayor que le traen del norte del Perú y también compra lanas, cintas, etc
Celinda tiene como sueño lograr que la municipalidad de Usquil les de autorización para semanalmente realizar una exposición de sus trabajos en la plaza de armas o en algún mercado en donde vender sus carteras, petates, bolsas, sombreros, etc
texts.en:
Sra. Celinda A. A. is 45 years old and lives in the District of Usquil, Otuzco Province, Department of La Libertad - Perú. This entrepreneur completed her studies through the 5th year of secondary school. She is a single mother and a member of the Communal Bank “Cachanchugo II”.

She wanted to study nursing after she finished high school, but her father denied her the opportunity and asked her to engage in farming. However, she decided to travel to Trujillo to get a job and pay for educational expenses on her own. She arrived in Trujillo at the age of 19 and worked for an Italian family as a nanny for 3 years. After she turned 21, she fell in love with the father of her child. He did not want to take responsibility for her or the baby after she became pregnant, so she returned to her hometown of Cachanchugo and started working on the farm. She began breeding guinea pigs and learned how to weave reeds grown in the area to make purses, seat covers, mats, hats, etc.

Celinda spends her time weaving reeds and also recruits other young women to increase production making purses, satchels, bags, and hats to sell in the city of Cajamarca. She used her first loan of 300 soles to buy reeds, ribbons, wool, yarn, etc.

With her current loan of 1000 soles, she will buy reeds at wholesale that are shipped in from northern Peru. She will also buy wool, ribbons, etc.

Celinda hopes to get a permit from the town of Usquil to exhibit her works every week in the central plaza or at a market where she can sell purses, satchels, bags, hats, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase reeds, wool, ribbons, etc.

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es:
La señora  MARIA MAGDALENA V. Q. , tiene 50 años, vive en el distrito de LA ESPERANZA , provincia de TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco Comunal ESPERANZA UNIDA.
La empresaria presenta estudios hasta 5to de secundaria .
MARIA MAGDALENA está casada, tiene 6 hijo y solo 2 dependen económicamente de ella una porque se encuentra estudiando la carrera de enfermería técnica y la última porque se encuentra en el colegio.
MARIA MAGDALENA se dedica a la venta de verduras, menestras cocinadas y fruta en el mercado cercano a su casa.
El primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió comprando sacos de menestra la por mayor , verduras y frutas.
Este crédito de 500 nuevos soles lo utilizará para  comprar verduras, frutas y menestras al por mayor.
MARIA MAGDALENA sueña con  tener una tienda de productos alimenticios en su casa y evitar el  estar todos los días armando su puesto porque se encuentra enferma de los riñones.

loans.use: lo utilizara para  comprar verduras y frutas, menestras al por mayor .

loans.name: Nicolaza Jesús

texts.es:
La señora NICOLAZA JESÚS Y. R., tiene 44 años, vive en el distrito de LA ESPERANZA , provincia de TRUJILLO, departamento La Libertad – Perú.
Pertenece al Banco MUJERES EN ACCION.
La empresaria presenta estudios superiores de Enfermería Técnica, no pudo ejercer porque al finalizar su carrera quedó embarazada y se dedico al hogar y al cuidado de sus hijos.
Nicolaza está casada y tiene 2 hijos en edad escolar.  Se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza como: talcos, cremas, colonias, joyas, perfumes, shampoo, etc, los mismos que distribuye en diferentes puestos del mercado que esta cerca a su casa y también vende directamente a sus vecinos, amistades, profesoras y madres de familia del centro educativo de su hijos.
El primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles lo invirtió en la compra de mas productos de belleza.
Este crédito de 2,500 nuevos soles lo utilizará para comprar productos de belleza al por mayor para poder tener en stock luego venderlos a precio de catalogó y poder aumentar así sus ganancias.
Nicolaza  es actualmente capitana de un grupo de 15 vendedoras de la empresa de productos de belleza que vende, lo cual le permite obtener los productos a menos costo y poder ganar mas.
NICOLAZA sueña con tener un stand en un centro comercial de Trujillo en donde pueda vender sus productos con mayor rapidez.

loans.use: lo utilizara para comprar productos de belleza al por mayor

loans.name: Doris

texts.es:
Doris es una persona trabajadora y jovial, ella  tiene 30 años de edad y es madre de tres niños, ella se dedica a la costura (lencería) para ello cuenta con una máquina de coser y una remalladota.  Su esposo se dedica a la venta de madera. 
Forma parte del Banco Comunal “ Las  Heroínas” desde hace un año. Doris empezó con un préstamo de 300 soles.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1800 soles, ella  invertirá parte de este dinero en la compra de telas, hilos, elástico, y la otra parte invertirá en el mantenimiento de su motocarro. 
La meta de Doris es tener su propio taller de costura y también tener un restaurante.
texts.en:
Doris is a hard worker and cheerful person. She is 30 years old and a mother of 3 children. She is a seamstress (linen goods) for which she uses a sewing machine and an industrial sewing machine. Her husband sells lumber.

Since a year ago, she is part of the Communal Bank “The Heroines.” Doris started with a loan of 300 soles. With this loan of S/.1800 soles, she will invest part of the money to buy fabrics, threads, and elastic; the other part she will invest in the maintenance of her motorcycle taxi.

Doris’ goals are to have her own sewing shop and have a restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabrics, threads, elastics, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of cosmetics in bulk

loans.name: God Time Is The Best Group

texts.en:
God Time is the Best is a group of 5 borrowers led by Bandu S.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Bandu is 28 years old and married with 2 children, ages 4 and 11. She also cares of a child who was orphaned in the war. All of her children are in school. Bandu was unable to attend school, although she enjoyed it, because the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia.

Bandu’s sells gasoline from her roadside stall. She has run her business for 6 years and is successful because her customers like her personality and work ethic – she stays open long hours for them. She’s taking the loan to increase her inventory of gasoline, which she purchases in Monrovia, to meet the demand of the growing economy. Her dream is to expand her business so that, one day, she can have a full gas station in town. With the profits from her business, Bandu dreams of sending her kids to college.

loans.use: Purchase gasoline wholesale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: le stockage de mais

loans.name: One Work #19 Group

texts.en:
One Work #19 is a group of 5 borrowers led by Bandu B.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Bandu is 38 years old and married. She has 2 children, ages 15 and 20. Her oldest is in the 8th grade. Bandu attended high school but was forced to drop out of high school in the 10th grade. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Bandu’s sells retail dry goods, including onions, vitta, and pasta that she buys wholesale in nearby Guinea and sells in a temporary market stall in the Kolahu Central Market. She has run her business for 3 years and is successful because of the way she treats her customers. She’s taking the loan to increase her inventory to meet increased demand. Her dream is to expand her business so that, one day, she can have the biggest table in the central market. With the profits from her business, Bandu dreams of sending her youngest child to university.

loans.use: Purchase onions, vitta, and pasta

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: stockpiling maize

loans.name: Togetherness #1 Group

texts.en:
Togetherness #1 is a group of 5 borrowers led by Sangay M. who live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Watta is 20 years old and married with 1 newborn child. Sangay was unable to attend school, although she enjoyed it, because the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Sangay’s sells dry goods, including slippers, children’s clothes, and toiletries that she buys wholesale in nearby Guinea and sells in a temporary market stall on the Kolahu-Foya highway. She has run her business for 3 years and is successful because of the way she treats her customers. She’s taking the loan to increase her inventory to meet increased demand. Her dream is to expand her business so that, one day, she can have the biggest table in the central market. With the profits from her business, Sangay dreams of sending her child to school.

loans.use: Purchase slippers, childrens's clothes, and toiletries

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
God is Able is a group of 5 borrowers led by Martin J. who live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Martin is 23 years old and married. He has a 2-year-old child and he also cares for a child who was orphaned in the war. Martin was able to attend school, but dropped out in the 9th grade when the war came to Lofa County. He lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Martin’s sells dry goods, including dry biscuits, palm oil, and clothes that he buys wholesale from nearby Guinea and sells in a temporary market stall in the Kolahu Central Market, Turlay Quarter. He has run his business for 3 years and is successful because of the way he treats his customers. He’s taking the loan to increase his inventory to meet increased demand. His dream is to expand her business so that, one day, he can have the biggest table in the central market. With the profits from his business, Martin dreams of building his own house and sending his child to school.

loans.use: Purchase biscuits, palm oil, and clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buying foodstuffs such as rice, tinned tomatoes, sugar, oil, etc.

loans.name: United Sisters #1 Group

texts.en:
United Sisters #1 is a group of 5 borrowers led by Jenneh J.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Jenneh is 28 years old and married with 2 children, ages 3 and 8. Jenneh was able to attend school, but dropped out in the 8th grade when the war came to Lofa County. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia.

Jenneh’s is a hairdresser in central Kolahu. She has run her business for 3 years and is successful because of the way she treats her customers -- with great haircuts and a smile. She’s taking the loan to purchase hair products. Her dream is to expand her business so she can one day have a permanent salon. With the profits from her business, Jenneh dreams of building her own house and sending all her children to school.

loans.use: Purchase hair products

loans.name: Bomba #1 Group

texts.en:
Bomba #1 is a group of 5 borrowers led by Bamma L.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Bamma is 47 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 8 and 25. Her youngest is in the 3rd grade. She was unable to attend school, although she enjoyed it, because the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Bamma sells dry meat, which she buys wholesale, prepares, and sells in a temporary market stall alongside approximately 100 other vendors of various trades. She is successful because her customers like her personality and the way she prepares the meat. She’s taking the loan to purchase raw meat to prepare and sell. Her dream is to expand her business so that, one day, she can build a permanent shop. With the profits from her business, Bamma dreams of raising her family well and sending all her children to the school that she was unable to attend.

loans.use: Purchase raw meat wholesale for preparation to sell

loans.name: Barna's Group

texts.en:
Pay On Time is a group of 5 borrowers led by Barna M. who live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Barna is 40 years old and married with 5 children ages 8-22. She also cares for 7 children who were orphaned in the war. Barna was unable to attend school, although she enjoyed it, because the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Barna’s sells dry goods, including palm oil, ground nuts, paper products, and toiletries that she buys wholesale in nearby Guinea and sells in a temporary market stall on the Kolahu-Foya highway. She has run her business for 3 years and is successful because of the way she treats her customers. She’s taking the loan to increase her inventory to meet increased demand. Her dream is to expand her business so that, one day, she can have the biggest table in the central market. With the profits from her business, Barna dreams of sending her younger children to school.

loans.use: Purchase palm oil, ground nuts, and paper products

loans.name: Arleni

texts.es:
La señora Arleni, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Decididas”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es conviviente, tiene 42 años y es madre de 02  hijos, 01 que aun están a cargo de ella. 

La fortaleza y la perseverancia que le caracteriza, le motivó a crear su propio negocio de venta mercería, ubicada en el Mercado Central de Ciudad. Día a día fue ganando clientela y con el buen trato que les brinda y los precio bajos que oferta, tiene muy buenas ventas. Actualmente continúa con este negocio pero ya ampliando con otros productos considerando la demanda que hoy en día se esta dando. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, comprará  más productos para surtir su negocio como cuadros, portafotos, artículos para regalos  como accesoR. de pulseras, anillos y collares, también algunos productos de higiene personal.

Ella manifiesta que trabaja con mucho optimismo, agradeciendo la oportunidad de contar con préstamos que le ayudan a desarrollarse como mujer y pequeña empresaria.
texts.en:
Mrs. Arleni belongs to the “Mujeres Decididas” (Decisive Women) Community Bank, in the Tarapoto District, in the department of San Martin. She has a partner, is 42 years old and is the mother of two children (one still lives at home and is a dependent) With the fortitude and perseverance that is part of her character, she was motivated to begin her own business selling merchandise. The business is located in the central market of the city. Her client base grows each day. With the good service she provides and the low prices she offers, she has good sales. Actually, she will continue with this business but will make it larger by offering other products. She is doing this after taking in account the current demands for her merchandise. With this loan of 1,500.00 soles, she will buy a larger variety of products for her business such as notebooks, photo holders and gift articles such as accessories like watches, rings and necklaces. She will also offer personal hygiene products. Arleni is an optimistic worker, thankful for the opportunity to count on loans that help with women and small business development.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy products to add to her inventory.

loans.name: My God #1 Group

texts.en:
My God #1 is a group of 5 borrowers led by Lusu J.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Lusu is 25 years old  and married with 4 children, ages 1-6. She also cares for 2 children who were orphaned in the war. Lusu was unable to attend school, although she enjoyed it, because the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Lusu’s sells dry goods, including clothing, palm oil, ground nuts, paper products, and beverages that she buys wholesale from nearby Guinea and sells in a temporary market stall on the Kolahu-Foya highway. She has run her business for 2 years and is successful because of the way she treats her customers. She’s taking the loan to increase her inventory to meet increased demand. Her dream is to expand her business so that, one day, she can have the biggest table in the central market. With the profits from her business Lusu dreams of sending her children to school.

loans.use: Purchase clothing, palm oil, nuts, and paper products

loans.name: Merith

texts.es:
La señora Merith, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Decididas”,  Distrito D. Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento D. San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 37 años, 03 hijos que aun depenD. D. ella.

Merith, se dedica ya 02 años a la Venta D. Kinkones, para implementarse y aumentar mas su negocio, decidió sacar un primer crédito D. S/. 300.00, donD. poco fue incrementando sus productos.
Sus clientes ya conocen el tipo D. actividad que realiza  y saben del trabajo que realiza, tiene mucha acogida.

En la Actualidad continua con el mismo negocio y ahora ya tiene una clientela fija que día a día compran sus kinkones, entre ellos están sus amigos, familiares y vecinos, le va muy bien y mensualmente genera sus propios ingresos y con el carisma que tiene sus ventas le salen a pedir D. boca.

Con este préstamo D. S/ 1,000.00, comprará 30 kinkones, realiza sus pedidos D. la Ciudad D. Trujillo, donD. lo envían quincenalmente. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá en el pago D. flete.

Merith, se siente muy contenta por lo logrado, feliz por que en su negocio le va muy bien. Esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla en iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Sra. Merith is a member of the Communal Bank “Mujeres Decididas” (Determined Women), which is located in the District of Tarapoto, San Martín Province, Department of San Martín. She is 37 years old, married, and has 3 dependent children.

For the past 2 years, Merith has been selling kinkones (a layered cookie that contains fillings of peanuts, pineapple, and sweetened milk). In order to start and grow her business, she decided to obtain her first loan of 300 soles to purchase more products. Her customers are familiar with her business and have been very receptive.

Merith continues to run her business and now has a steady clientele who buy kinkones on a daily basis. Her customers incluD. friends, relatives, and neighbors. Business continues to do well and generates a monthly income. Due to her charismatic personality, Merith has obtained many sales through word of mouth.

With her loan of 1000 soles, she will buy 30 boxes of kinkones. She places her orders in Trujillo every 2 weeks. Some of the money will be used to pay for the shipping costs.

Merith is very happy with what she has accomplished and that her business continues to do very well. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business and providing support to many other women who want to grow as entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase boxes of "kinkones"

loans.name: Yapuchiri 7 Group

texts.es:
Yapuchiri 7 es un grupo de 7 señoras que se agruparon recientemente para acceder al préstamo, una de las integrantes es María T. de 52 años, ella desde su juventud ha incursionado en el negocio del macramé en mantas, una actividad familiar ya que aprendió de sus hermanos, actualmente se ha visto en la necesidad de contar con un poco de capital para comprar lana y seguir en su negocio, María entrega sus productos a diferentes  tiendas de la feria 16 de Julio.
Al igual que María las demás integrantes del grupo tambien tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de salteñas, repuestos de celulares, viéveres y ropa y todas necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería.
texts.en:
Yapuchiri 7 is a group of 7 ladies that got together to receive a loan. One of the members, María T., is 52 years old, and since her childhood she has been involved in the business of blankets and macramé items, a family activity that she learned from her brothers. Recently, she needs money to buy wool to keep her business; María delivers her products to different stores in Feria 16 de Julio (a street fair).

The rest of the members of the group also have their own businesses like the sale of “salteñas” (pastries filled with meat, vegetables and spicy sauce), spare parts for cell phones, groceries, and clothes. All need a loan to acquire the merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw materials or merchandise.

loans.name: Tarlay United Group

texts.en:
Tarlay United is a group of 5 borrowers led by Jasa K.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Jasa  is 31 years old and single with 3 children ages 5-15. All of her children are in school. She also supports 2 children who were orphaned in the war. Jasa was unable to attend school, although she enjoyed it, because the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia.

Jasa’s sells clothing, including slippers, shirts, pants, and underwear, which she buys wholesale in nearby Guinea and sells in a temporary market stall on the Kolahu-Foya highway. She has run her business for 4 years and is successful because of her business and finance skills. She’s taking the loan to increase her inventory of clothing which sell well in the rainy season. Her dream is to expand her business so that one day she can have the biggest table in the central market and ultimately her own permanent shop. With the profits from her business, Jasa dreams of building her own house.

loans.use: Purchase slippers, shirts, and pants

loans.name: Looking Town #1 Group

texts.en:
Looking Town #1 is a group of 5 borrowers led by Famata K.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. 

Fatama is 35 years old and single, and she has 3 children, ages 10-20. All of her children are in school. Famata was unable to attend school, although she enjoyed it, because the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. She lives in the remote city of Kolahu in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Famata’s sells clothing, including slippers, shirts, pants, and underwear that she buys wholesale in nearby Guinea and sells in a temporary market stall on the Kolahu-Foya highway. She has run her business for 3 years and is successful because of her people skills. She’s taking a loan to increase her inventory of clothing, which sell well in the rainy season. Her dream is to expand her business so that, one day, she can have the biggest table in the central market and ultimately her own permanent shop. With the profits from her business, Famata dreams of building her own house.

loans.use: Purchase slippers, shirts, pants, and underwear

loans.name: Puerta Del Sol Group

texts.es:
Barbara S. de 75 años hace 10 años aproximadamente trabaja con la familia de Pro Mujer, cuenta que  para acceder al préstamo tubo que capacitarse tres meses, al inicio eran pocos, pero poco a poco las mujeres se fueron agrupando (vecinas y amigas), en las capacitaciones les orientaban en como administrar su negocio. Actualmente pertenece al grupo “Puera del Sol” que a su vez es parte del Centro Focal “Alto Lima”.
Barbara tiene 6 hijos, todos casados y dos de ellos aprendieron del negocio que ella maneja, que es la elaboración de pitas o sogas.
Las demás integrantes tambien tienen sus propios negocios, algunas se dedican a la producción de mantas y chompas, otras de dedican a la comercialización de productos tales como ropa de bebe, mochilas, abarrotes. Todas necesitan del préstamo para adquirir materia prima y mercadería.
texts.en:
Barbara S. is 75 years old and for approximately 10 years has been working with the Pro Mujer family. She notes that in order to access the loan she had to train for three months. At the beginning, there were only a few of them, but gradually women began to form groups (neighbors and friends). In the training, they were taught how to manage their businesses. Currently, she belongs to the "Puerta del Sol" group which in turn is part of the "Alto Lima" Centro Focal. Barbara has six children, all of whom are married and two of whom learned the business that she manages, which is making string or rope. The other members also have their own businesses. Some are dedicated to the production of blankets and sweaters while others are dedicated to selling products such as baby clothes, backpacks, and groceries. All need a loan to acquire basic materials and merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise and basic materials.

loans.name: United Group

texts.en:
United is a group of 5 borrowers led by Watta K.. They live in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia. Watta  is 23 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 1 and 7. All of her children are in school. She also supports a child who was  orphaned in the war. Watta was unable to attend school, although she enjoyed it, because the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide and, therefore, school was considered unnecessary. She lives in remote Kolahu City in rural Lofa County, the breadbasket of Liberia. 

Watta designs, sews, and sells clothing including slippers, shirts, and pants. She buys the raw materials wholesale in nearby Guinea and sells the clothing in a temporary market stall on the Kolahu-Foya highway. She has run her business for 5 years and is successful because  she produces quality clothing. 

Watta is taking a loan to purchase additional thread and fabric so she can produce more clothes to meet increasing demand. Her dream is to expand her business so that, one day, she can have the biggest table in the central market and ultimately her own permanent shop. With the profits from her business, Watta dreams of sending her children to college.

loans.use: Purchase thread and fabric

loans.name: Unity Group #1

texts.en:
Bandu is a 45-year-old married woman with three children between the ages of 10 and 20. She also cares for one child who was orphaned in the war. All of her children are in school. Bandu’s business is a cook shop: a fast food roadside café for workers in the fields and other general laborers. She has run her business for 10 years and is successful because her customers like her personality and work ethic (she stays open long hours for them), and the way she prepares the food.

Bandu was unable to attend school because, although she enjoyed it, the cultural norm was for girls to rely on their husbands to provide, and therefore school was considered unnecessary. She lives in remote Kolahu city in rural Lofa County – the breadbasket of Liberia. She’s taking out this loan to increase her food stores of rice, oil, salt and meat to meet the demands of the growing local economy. Her dream is to grow her business so that she can have a real restaurant in town one day. With the profits from her business, Bandu dreams of sending her kids to college.

Bandu M. leads a group of five borrowers living in Kolahu, Lofa County, Liberia – Unity Group #1.

loans.use: To purchase rice, oil and salt

loans.name: Juana Margarita

texts.es:
La señora Juana Margarita es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”, del  distrito de J., provincia de Chucuito,  departamento de Puno, ella tiene 43 años de edad,  es casada y vive actualmente  con su esposo, esta al cuidado de sus tiene 3 hijos, ella tiene estudios de primaria incompleta (4to de primaria)

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace más de un año, su primer préstamo fue de S/300.00 nuevos soles monto que le sirvió para adquirir mercadería para su negocio de venta de golosinas, galletas y gaseosas.

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo adicional S/ 1000.00 nuevos soles con el préstamo ella podrá adquirir mas mercadería en golosinas, galletas, gaseosas y también en material para elaborar productos de bordados en bayeta lo cual los  venderá en diferentes ferias de la región con mas frecuencia en la Isla de los Uros.

Su mayor deseo es comprarse un carro para facilitar  el traslado de su mercadería, y que su casa este totalmente concluida como ella quiere, que sus hijos sean buenos  profesionales para que no tengan problemas económicos en el futuro.

A ella le gusta las reuniones, la puntualidad, los ahorros y sus ganancias.

loans.use: Para la compra de golosinas, galletas, gaseosas y produtos para bordados.

loans.name: Sara Maria

texts.es:
La señora Sara Maria es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”,  del  distrito de Juli, provincia de Chucuito, departamento de Puno, ella tiene 20 años de edad,  conviviente hace 3 meses y vive actualmente  con su pareja,  tiene 1 hijo de un año de edad que es la razón de su vida, ella tiene estudios secundarios completos  (5to de secundaria).

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace   un año, su primer préstamo fue de S/500.00 nuevos soles monto que le sirvió para adquirir mercadería para realizar productos de bordado en bayeta.

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo adicional S/ 1000.00 nuevos soles con el préstamo ella podrá adquirir mas mercadería como bayetas ,lana hilos de tal manera podrá  elaborar mayor cantidad de productos de bordado en bayetas  y las venderá en diferentes ferias de la región.

Su sueño es tener casa propia y que su negocio crezca mas y que su hijo sea profesional para que no tengan problemas económicos en el futuro.

De las reuniones  le gusta los ahorros, sus ganancias y compartir experiencias con las otras socias.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sarah Maria is a member of the "Santa Rosa de Lima" Community Bank, Juli district, province of Chucuito, Puno State. She is 20 years old, has a 1 year old child and lives with her partner since 3 months ago. She graduated from high school.

She has been working with the Manuela Ramos association for the last year. Her first loan was $500.00 soles which she invested in the purchase of materials for cloth embroidered products.

She is asking for an additional loan of $350, that will be invested in the purchase of embroidery materials such as, to be able to increase her production and sell her products at the markets in the region.

Her dream is to own a house, to grow her business and for her child to have a college degree and do not have economic problems in the future. About the meetings, she likes saving, earning, and sharing experiences with the other members. .

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Isidora Narcisa

texts.es:
La señora Isidora Narcisa  es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa D. Lima”, del  distrito D. Juli, provincia D. Chucuito, departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 55 años D. edad,  es casada y vive actualmente  con su esposo,  tiene 4 hijos, 1 D. ellos  tiene su familia pero todos viven al lado D. ella están al amparo D. su madre ya que todavía no trabajan, ella  tiene estudios D. primaria completa (6to grado)

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace más D. un año, su primer préstamo fue D. S/300.00 nuevos soles monto que le sirvió para adquirir insumos para la preparación D. venta D. comida ya que ella tiene un puesto D. venta D. comida en el mercado D. juli.

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo adicional S/ 300.00 nuevos soles con el préstamo ella podrá adquirir mas productos e insumos para implementar su negocio D. comida.

Su sueño es salir adelante, que sus hijos sean buenos  profesionales para que no tengan problemas económicos en el futuro.

Del Banco Comunla. le gustan los ahorros, sus ganancias y los temas educativos a la vez piD. que los próximos temas D. capacitación sean en la preparación D. diferentes platos lo cual le serviría mucho en el futuro.
texts.en:
Sra. Isidora Narcisa is a member of the Communal Bank “Santa Rosa D. Lima”, which is located in the District of Juli, Chucuito Province, Department of Puno. She is 55 years old, married, and has 4 children. One child has a family, but they all live nearby and help their mother because they still do not have jobs. Sra. Isidora has a 6th graD. education.

She has been working with Manuela Ramos for more than a year. Her first loan in the amount of 300 soles was used to purchase supplies for preparing food that she sells from her vending stall in the Juli Market.

She is currently requesting another loan of 300 soles to purchase additional products and supplies for her food business.

Sra. Isidora dreams of getting ahead and that her children become successful professionals who do not have financial problems in the future. She enjoys her profits and the savings and educational seminars provided by her Communal Bank. Her next training session will cover the preparation of different dishes, which should benefit her greatly in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for food preparation

loans.name: Mariana Mery

texts.es:
La señora Marina Mery  es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”, del  distrito de Juli, provincia de Chucuito, departamento de Puno, ella tiene 30 años de edad,  es conviviente hace 5 años  y vive actualmente  con su pareja,  tiene 1 hijo, ella  estudio hasta concluir   superior completo.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace   un año, su primer préstamo fue de S/500.00 nuevos soles monto que le sirvió para adquirir mercadería para realizar productos de bordado en bayeta.

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo adicional S/ 700.00 nuevos soles con el préstamo ella podrá adquirir mas mercadería como bayeta, lanas de tal manera producir mas y las venderá en diferentes ferias de la región a veces entraga al por mayor es por ello que ella require mas capital. Ella manifiesta que vende de todo de acuerdo a la época en que estamos así como en tiempo escolar ella vende útiles escolares y así sucesivamente.

Su mayor sueño es conseguir un buen capital y tener su propio restaurante  y  conseguir trabajo como docente, que su hijo sea un buen  profesional para que no tengan problemas económicos en el futuro.

De las reuniones  le gusta los ahorros, sus ganancias, los temas educativos y compartir experiencias con las otras socias.
texts.en:
Sra. Mariana Mery is a member of the Communal Bank “Santa Rosa de Lima”, which is located in the District of Juli, Chucuito Province, Department of Puno. She is 30 years old and has been in a common law marriage for 5 years. She and her partner have 1 child. Sra. Mariana Mery completed her college education.

She has been working with Manuela Ramos for 1 year. Her first loan in the amount of 500 soles was used to purchase supplies for making embroidered fabrics.

At the moment, she is requesting another loan of 700 soles to buy more products, such as flannel and wool, so that she can produce more embroideries to sell at various regional fairs or through wholesale delivery since this requires additional capital. Sra. Mariana Mery tells us that she sells other products based on the time of the year. Since school has started, she sells items such as school supplies and other related merchandise.

Her biggest dream is to secure enough capital to open a restaurant or get a job as a teacher. She hopes that her child becomes a successful professional who does not have financial problems in the future. Sra. Mariana Mery enjoys her savings, earnings, the educational seminars provided by her Communal Bank, and sharing her experiences with other members.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flannel & wool in different colors

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es:
La señora Andrea  es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”, del  distrito de Juli, provincia de Chucuito,  departamento de Puno, ella tiene 51 años de edad,  ella es casada,   tiene 9 hijos pero vive solo con 4 de ellos, ella no tiene estudios los escasos recursos económicos no le permitieron estudiar.
